title: Sociology 490S - Occupations and Status
text:
Name
Email
Office
Drop-in Hours




Prof.Â Lynn Smith-Lovin (she/her)
smithlov@duke.edu
Reuben-Cooke 339
schedule by email


Em Maloney (they/them)
em.k.maloney@duke.edu
Reuben-Cooke 141
Thursdays 1-2pm or schedule by email
zoom link if on zoom: https://duke.zoom.us/j/92182624941




Course Description
This course is a senior research seminar using a sociological lens to explore the relationship between occupations and social status. We will begin by returning to classical sociological theory to understand precisely what status is and what role occupations serve in the context of society and social interaction. Next, we will review the debate surrounding measuring occupational status and how operationalizing it precisely has important consequences for downstream social research. Finally, we will read and evaluate research showing how status is linked to demographic characteristics of occupations, how status â€˜plays outâ€™ on the job, and mechanisms by which occupational status is maintained through institutions.
In exploring these questions, we will privilege one sociological theory: affect control theory, as a way of measuring culture broadly and occupational status in particular. This theory is a formal model of social interaction with tools for running simulations and developing testable hypotheses that will guide your original research throughout the semester. As this is a capstone course, the major portion of your grade for this class will be an original research project on a question related to occupational status that you will complete throughout the course. Throughout the semester, assignments will lead you throughout the research project, allowing you to get feedback from instructors and your peers as you refine your research question and decide on appropriate methods, complete your literature review, conduct your analyses, and finally, write the full draft of the paper.
To serve both of these aims: a thorough understanding of the current landscape of sociological work on occupations and status and the generation of an original research project, this course will generally have a split Wednesday / Friday structure. On Wednesdays, we will follow a typical course format with lectures and class activities linked to readings you will read before class. Fridays will often be more of a lab style. In the first half of the semester, Fridays will be devoted to learning affect control theory and its simulation tools. During this portion, approximately every other week you will be assigned a short lab assignment to help you become familiar with the theory. In the second half, Fridays will be for working through the assignments that are linked to your final research paper and getting feedback on your work.


Course Objectives
By the end of this course, you will be able to:

Assess different methods of measuring occupational status and tie them to relevant social theoristsâ€™ paradigms
Design a research project on a topic related to occupations and status
Understand the basic tenets of Affect Control Theory and apply them to substantive, original research on occupations
Demonstrate how being in differently valued occupations affects individualsâ€™ material, social, and emotional outcomes.
Interpret evidence for and against current debates in the sociology of work and status, including the gender devaluation hypothesis.



Course Grading

Class participation (15%)
Labs (15%)

There are 3 labs, each equal to 5% of your grade

Assignments (20%)

Research Question (5%)
Annotated Bibliography (5%)
Literature Review (5%)
Methods Plan (5%)

Final Research Paper (40%)



Attendance Policy
Attendance in this class is mandatory (conditional on you being well enough to attend - please do not come to class if you are sick!). Unexcused absences will decrease your participation grade in the course.


Technology
We will be doing online activities and labs throughout the class; please bring your laptops or tablets to class days, especially Fridays. The course website can be found here: https://ekmaloney.github.io/soc490s/ and is where you can find all course materials, including readings, labs, and assignments.


Course communication
If you have any questions about the course material, lectures, or missing class, please email Em at em.k.maloney@duke.edu. If you have any questions about grading, please email Professor Smith-Lovin at smithlov@duke.edu


Student Success
If you are having trouble completing assignments or understanding the materials, please consult with us about appropriate course preparation and readiness strategies as needed. Either send us an email or visit office hours describing the personal or academic difficulties you are facing. We may also direct you to other resources on campus.

The Academic Resource Center (ARC) offers free services to all students, including peer tutoring, learning consultations, ADHD/LD coaching and help with online learning.
If you are concerned about your physical or mental health, DukeReach can connect you with departments across campus to get you help, and you can contact Counseling & Psychological Services (CAPS) directly for counseling services. You can also reach 24/7 mental health support through Blue Devils Care.



Academic Accommodations
If you need to request accommodation for a disability, you should contact the Disability Management System (DMS) office. We will work with that office to provide you with equal access to course materials and make accommodations.


Academic Integrity
As a student, you should abide by Dukeâ€™s Community Standard, which states: Duke University is a community dedicated to scholarship, leadership, and service and to the principles of honesty, fairness, respect and accountability. Citizens of this community commit to reflect upon and uphold these principles in all academic and nonacademic endeavors, and to protect and promote a culture of integrity. To uphold the Duke Community Standard:

I will not lie, cheat, or steal in my academic endeavors.
I will conduct myself honorably in all my endeavors; and
I will act if the Standard is compromised.

It is the responsibility of the student to understand and follow Duke policies regarding academic integrity, including doing oneâ€™s own work, following proper citations of sources, and adhering to guidance around group work. Please speak with me to get any clarification about this course.

text:

(Boyle and Rogers 2023; Jacobs and Quinn 2022; Kroska and Harkness 2006, 2011)
Emotions
(Doan 2012; Langford and Mackinnon 2000a; Lively and Powell 2006; Lively, Steelman, and Powell 2010; Lively and Heise 2014; Maloney 2023)
Gender & Race
(Kroska and Cason 2019; Langford and Mackinnon 2000b; Wingfield, Hordge-Freeman, and Smith-Lovin 2018)
Culture: subcultures and/or cultural change
(Quinn et al. 2023; Boyle and Walker 2016; Bergstrand 2019; MacKinnon and Luke 2002)
Defining interactions
(Boyle and McKinzie 2015; Francis 1997; Kelly 2023)
Inequality in cultural meanings
(Rogers 2019; Rogers, SchrÃ¶der, and Scholl 2013)




References

Bergstrand, Kelly. 2019. â€œThe Advantaged Cause: Affect Control Theory and Social Movements.â€ Socius 5 (January): 2378023119841811. https://doi.org/10.1177/2378023119841811.


Boyle, Kaitlin M., and Ashleigh E. McKinzie. 2015. â€œResolving Negative Affect and Restoring Meaning: Responses to Deflection Produced by Unwanted Sexual Experiences.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 78 (2): 151â€“72. https://doi.org/10.1177/0190272514564073.


Boyle, Kaitlin M., and Kimberly B. Rogers. 2023. â€œSelf-Sentiments and Depressive Symptoms: A Longitudinal Analysis.â€ American Behavioral Scientist 67 (1): 36â€“59. https://doi.org/10.1177/00027642211066031.


Boyle, Kaitlin M., and Lisa Slattery Walker. 2016. â€œThe Neutralization and Denial of Sexual Violence in College Party Subcultures.â€ Deviant Behavior 37 (12): 1392â€“1410. https://doi.org/10.1080/01639625.2016.1185862.


Doan, Long. 2012. â€œA Social Model of Persistent Mood States.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 75 (3): 198â€“218. https://doi.org/10.1177/0190272512451157.


Francis, Linda E. 1997. â€œIdeology and Interpersonal Emotion Management: Redefining Identity in Two Support Groups.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 60 (2): 153â€“71. https://doi.org/10.2307/2787102.


Jacobs, Susan, and Joseph Quinn. 2022. â€œCultural reproduction of mental illness stigma and stereotypes.â€ Social Science & Medicine (1982) 292 (January): 114552. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.socscimed.2021.114552.


Kelly, Chelsea Rae. 2023. â€œâ€œThe Situation Sounds Sketchyâ€: Institutional Rule-Breaking and a Qualitative Case for Quantifying Culture.â€ American Behavioral Scientist 67 (2): 290â€“310. https://doi.org/10.1177/00027642211066035.


Kroska, Amy, and Trent C. Cason. 2019. â€œThe Gender Gap in Business Leadership: Exploring an Affect Control Theory Explanation.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 82 (1): 75â€“97. https://doi.org/10.1177/0190272518806292.


Kroska, Amy, and Sarah K. Harkness. 2006. â€œStigma Sentiments and Self-Meanings: Exploring the Modified Labeling Theory of Mental Illness.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 69 (4): 325â€“48. https://doi.org/10.1177/019027250606900403.


â€”â€”â€”. 2011. â€œCoping with the Stigma of Mental Illness: Empirically-Grounded Hypotheses from Computer Simulations.â€ Social Forces 89 (4): 1315â€“39. https://www.jstor.org/stable/41290131.


Langford, Tom, and Neil J. Mackinnon. 2000a. â€œThe Affective Bases for the Gendering of Traits: Comparing the United States and Canada.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 63 (1): 34â€“48. https://doi.org/10.2307/2695879.


â€”â€”â€”. 2000b. â€œThe Affective Bases for the Gendering of Traits: Comparing the United States and Canada.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 63 (1): 34â€“48. https://doi.org/10.2307/2695879.


Lively, Kathryn J., and David R. Heise. 2014. â€œEmotions in Affect Control Theory.â€ In, 51â€“75. Handbooks of Sociology and Social Research. New York, NY, US: Springer Science + Business Media. https://doi.org/10.1007/978-94-017-9130-4.


Lively, Kathryn J., and Brian Powell. 2006. â€œEmotional Expression at Work and at Home: Domain, Status, or Individual Characteristics?â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 69 (1): 17â€“38. https://www.jstor.org/stable/20141726.


Lively, Kathryn J., Lala Carr Steelman, and Brian Powell. 2010. â€œEquity, Emotion, and Household Division of Labor Response.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 73 (4): 358â€“79. https://www.jstor.org/stable/27896255.


MacKinnon, Neil J., and Alison Luke. 2002. â€œChanges in Identity Attitudes as Reflections of Social and Cultural Change.â€ The Canadian Journal of Sociology / Cahiers Canadiens de Sociologie 27 (3): 299â€“338. https://doi.org/10.2307/3341547.


Maloney, Em K. 2023. â€œThe Influence of Occupational Identity on Emotional Experience.â€ American Behavioral Scientist 67 (1): 100â€“124. https://doi.org/10.1177/00027642211066053.


Quinn, Joseph M., Robert E. Freeland, Kimberly B. Rogers, Jesse Hoey, and Lynn Smith-Lovin. 2023. â€œHow Cultural Meanings of Occupations in the U.S. Changed During the Covid-19 Pandemic.â€ American Behavioral Scientist 67 (1): 125â€“47. https://doi.org/10.1177/00027642211066041.


Rogers, Kimberly B. 2019. â€œIdentity Meanings and Categorical Inequality.â€ In, edited by Jan E. Stets and Richard T. Serpe, 0. Oxford University Press. https://doi.org/10.1093/oso/9780190873066.003.0013.


Rogers, Kimberly B., Tobias SchrÃ¶der, and Wolfgang Scholl. 2013. â€œThe Affective Structure of Stereotype Content: Behavior and Emotion in Intergroup Context.â€ Social Psychology Quarterly 76 (2): 125â€“50. https://doi.org/10.1177/0190272513480191.


Wingfield, Adia Harvey, Elizabeth Hordge-Freeman, and Lynn Smith-Lovin. 2018. â€œDoes the Job Matter? Diversity Officers and Racialized Stress.â€ In, 32:197â€“215. Research in the Sociology of Work. Emerald Publishing Limited. https://doi.org/10.1108/S0277-283320180000032013.
